description: This is Rahb, the Observation Team Supervisor who will be assisting you in this office.
Rahb patiently waits for you to listen to her directions, as she has more to tell you about the country of Zariba.
She motions to the other people in the room, encouraging you to speak to them.
You recognize this person as the Deputy Minister of Health, a very important partner for you in this process.
The Deputy Minister has nothing more to say to you.
The Deputy Minister has nothing more to say to you.
This is the Finance Minister, who has been brought in today to explain the financial situation in Zariba as it relates to the health sector.
The Finance Minister has nothing more to say to you.
The Finance Minister has nothing more to say to you.

This is the Director of Regional Health Services for the Highlands region of Zariba. As you understand, this person works under the Deputy Minister and is probably the most knowledgeable person here when it comes to healthcare in the Highlands.
I can explain a little bit more if you have the time.
The Regional Director of Health has nothing more to say to you.
A woman you imagine might come from the capitol stands before you. At first glance you notice she seems a bit annoyed and visibly distracted.
She's still waiting for her train, and looks like she's given up hope that it will ever come.
As you pass the well-dressed woman, you wish her luck on her trip to Zima.

A well-dressed middle-aged man sits on a bench, casually reading the world news. Next to him is a small bag filled with textbooks on the history of Zariba. You  notice a pin from a university on his jacket.
The professor looks eager to continue your conversation. He has more to say.
The professor reads a text book, 'The Zariban Nation.'

A young woman, maybe 19 years, is selling fruit from a well-stocked cart. Most of them you’ve never even seen before, and a perfume-like aroma wafts from a box of red berry clusters. She looks expectantly at you, smiling politely.
You catch the vendor's eye again as she finishes selling something that looks like citrus. She tells the customer it's her daughter's favorite.
The woman is packing up her cart, eager to get back to her family.

In the middle of the crowded marketplace, you see a man dressed in an impressive robe. He seems to be charming those around him as a small crowd gathers to listen to his sermon-like presentation. Behind him is an elaborate cart of small medallions, tokens, and jars, all different sizes and shapes. The sign reads "Medicine" in multiple languages.
The Medicine Merchant is still selling his wares, delivering the same sermon-like pitch to anyone who will listen.
As you watch more people buying the man’s goods, you wonder how much he earns, and how much of that money he passes on to Mr. Todd.

In the middle of the market there are two women in elaborate business-like dress. You notice a logo for one of the more popularly NGO organizations in the region pinned to their front pockets. They are in a heated discussion and you can listen in without interrupting.
The two NGO managers are still chatting.
They look in your direction with awkwardness, noticing you overheard their discussion. You feel its best to move on.
A patient sits on a chair on the deck of the clinic, waiting for her turn to be seen.
The patient coughs absently. It sounds nasty, but she's used to it.
She looks at the door, probably weighing cutting her losses and going back to work.
A tired looking man with a stethoscope around his neck stands in the doorway of the clinic. He appears to be a doctor of some sort.
Dr. Maramuta chews his pen while looking over a spreadsheet. He takes another pen from his lab coat to make notes.
You decide to let the doctor be. He's arguing with a nurse about how much time to spend with each patient.
A well-dressed woman stands observing the plantation. She has evidently just come from the larger plantation house up the path.
Looking at the plantation owner, you can only guess at her age. She's gotten a lot of sun and wind to make her look out home in the fields. She notices you looking at her.
She's focused on a bog at the back of the estate. Something needs her attention, and as she leaves, you notice she favors her left leg.
A pair of older men sit under the shade of a palm, playing some sort of tile-laying game. The gaming set is finely crafted from polished wood, but seems old and well worn. They chat as they play.
Eventually you get their attention away from the game. No mean feat, since one of them captured a piece and the other was loudly damning him for it.
You listen some more, but after that last capture, both men are more intent on the game.
A man leans up against a large piece of advanced farming equipment smoking a cigarette. It looks like he’s taking a break.
You continue to chat with the man, only distracted a little by his mech. You're surprised by how cool it is, a giant farming robot.
The man extinguishes his half-smoked cigarette and stashes it in the soft pack he keeps rolled in his sleeve. Time to get back to work.
A short man sits in the shade, tuning what looks like a harp. Haven’t you seen him somewhere before?
Probably? Maybe? It's almost as if you can't remember his face when you look away.
You turn away and try to--nope. Can't remember what he looks like. You try it two more times. He's amused and that's only more frustrating.

A woman who looks to be in her thirties crouches down among rows of fresh crops, harvesting the land’s bounty. Her movements are precise and efficient, like she has been doing this her whole life. She hums softly to herself as she works in rhythm with her motions. The only adornment on her otherwise spartan attire is a small locket dangling from her neck.
You notice the thin tan line from the locket's chain. While you're looking, she starts talking again.
She blows some dirt off her hand before running her fingers over the locket. All the while she detassels with her other hand.

You see a man in his forties reading a news magazine in the shade, slight perspiration beading along his receding hairline. The magazine looks like one from the newsstand at the train station, perhaps dropped by a careless traveler some time ago.
You look at the magazine. The man's reading an article about fall fashions, probably just to pass the time.
You want to talk with him some more, but you can't trust yourself not to remind him of what he's lost.

A middle-aged woman walks down the path from the train station. She looks preoccupied by something, and perhaps a little angry. She carries medical textbooks with her, including a volume on midwifery.
As you talk with the midwife, she shifts her weight back and forth, right and left. She likely stood for most of the day long journey here.
Her book on midwifery is new, but it's the seventh edition of the text. You wonder how old the title is.
A young man looking to be in his teens kicks a stone down the road. You notice a rolled-up flyer in his pocket that seems to be some sort of a "help wanted" notice.
There is a tension in his voice and you sympathize with his frustration. Still, you are not sure if his suggestions are helpful. Maybe he has more to say?
The teen seems uninterested in engaging with you any longer.

A herder is wrangling a small flock of flightless birds toward the market, taking care that none wander off. You notice a medallion around his neck that looks familiar to you. Many people in this area seem to be wearing them.

Whenever people speak of traditional medicine you feel uneasy due to your position. Yet the pride in his voice and the way his birds seem drawn to him reminds you of the genuine people who populate this beautiful land.
One of the herder's birds keeps gnawing on his ankle. You take this as a sign and leave him to his work.

An older man stands in front of a grand domicile. He grins broadly, gesturing emphatically as he speaks to a young woman who is clearly a customer of his. "Burn this incense before you sleep," you hear him say, "Every night for one month. No more and no less." The woman looks happy, and very grateful.
You wish he would stop smiling long enough for you to feel like he's actually talking to you. 'The cat who got the canary' pops into your mind.
You mutter some pleasantry as you excuse yourself, annoyed that everyone else's deference to the man rubbed off on you.

This man is clearly a merchant of some sort, with wares from all over Zariba. He calls out to people on the street, "Fresh fruit from Mile! Cigars from Crup! Technology from the Capitol! I have it all!"
While you talk with the merchant you admire his clothes. They aren't especially nice. They're plain, actually. But just fasionable enough to look presentable without evoking any one region of Zariba.
You would talk with the merchant more, ask him about travel around Zariba, but he's caught up in haggling with a customer over a Milean vase.
A short man sits in the shade, tuning what looks like a harp. Haven’t you seen him somewhere before?
You can't shake the feeling. Maybe he just has one of those faces.
You'd talk with him some more, but the way he looks at you, as if he knows you can't quite place him.
You meet a young woman standing outside on the street. You notice the insignia on her jacket belonging to the clinic in Crup.
After speaking to the Nurse's aid you feel like she is a trusted source.
She is trying to enjoy her day off, you should not bother her any longer.
An older woman stands with a young boy, probably her grandson. They seem a bit lost.
The grandmother is willing to talk with you, even as she wipes some smudge off her grandson's face.
As you walk away, you glance over your shoulder. She's doting on the boy enough to make him fussy.
A young man and woman, probably in their late teens, seem to be waiting to board an airship. They look very much alike. Probably they are brother and sister. Perhaps even twins.
While they talk, mostly for their benefit though technically answering your question, you look more closely. They have matching bracelets and that weird familiarity twins sometimes have.
You thank them for their time and wish you could dismiss what they said, although you suspect they're right about the hospitals' smell.
A woman fidgets with her flight suit, tightening a loose strap and pulling her zipper a little higher. She appears to be in her late 20s, and preparing to depart soon via airship.
As you talk, you can tell she isn't really looking at you, but at her airship. She has the ship's name, 'The Pleiades' stitched into her flight jacket.
After you're done with your questions, you listen politely as she describes her ship's seven engine system. It's all very complicated, but you feel good listening.
A man sits, tuning his harp. Haven’t you seen him somewhere before?
Love that nomad!
Love that nomad!
A woman you recognize as the hospital administrator sits at her desk, going over some of the day's paperwork.
You sense there is more she can help you with.
You should leave her to her work.
A woman sits in the waiting room, staring into space. Either she is waiting for her turn to see the doctor, or here with someone who is currently being examined.
The woman reaches over to touch your hand and thanks you for listening to her problems. You can tell she is eager to speak to you further.
You said your goodbyes and decide to leave to her rest before her appointment.
Her assortment of luggage marks this woman as a traveler, and her clothes and attitude tell you she is foreign. Where could she be going?
You recognize her clothing as Valerian silk and wonder if she found her way here on an airship.
You should make your way into the hospital.
A middle aged man is examining a medical chart of some kind. You recognize him as a doctor both by his attire and his nametag, Dr. Notega.
Dr. Notega has a lot to say about the state of health in Zariba. You trust he is a reliable source who might have more information for you.
You shake hands with the doctor, thanking for his time, and leaving him to his work.
The tall male nurse towers over everyone. Forehead scrunched in frustrated tension, he wipes a few beads of sweat from his brow.
Though not the most pleasant conversation, You remind yourself it is important to gather as much information as possible. Perhaps he has more to say?
The nurse seems flustered, but you understand the predictiment he is in and sympathize.
You recognize this person as the Deputy Minister of Health, a very important partner for you in this process.
You aren't sure what you were expecting for your coach but...no. This is it. Exactly. Right down to the baseball cap.
You heard Mr. Mokonanye used to be a police lieutenant and looking at him, you'd believe it.
The NGO Manager is a short man, and looks accustomed to worry. Or maybe his face is just like that.
Amina looks up from the stack of casefiles on her desk and smiles. You almost expect her to present you with fresh baked cookies.
The Clinic Manager is a big guy, with a big smile in his big beard. His smile lines compete with his frown lines, though.
You read 'Jaquilyn Appiah' on her nameplate, but when she shakes your hand she introduces herself as 'Jackie.'
The Supervisor seems all right angles: square shoulders and a sharp suit. Amicable, but not necessarily approachable.
You try to get the wiry man's attention, but even when he's talking to you his eyes dart away.
Your favorite traditional health practitioner.
Helps make your clinics special.

cities.description: Malcom is the line between more urbanized city environment and traditional farmland. The train station runs between Mile and the Capitol, and there is a ferry that departs to Valeria once a day.

Known far and wide as the "Heart of the Highlands," Kibari is one of the largest settlements in the Zariban interior. The town is a center of commerce for the area since it's "on the way to everywhere," and is a cultural melting pot with people from all over the country.

Valeria is one of the more affluent cities, and not part of the highlands region of Zariba. Unlike the rest of the country, the climate here is arid, and wealth and land are consolidated under entrenched “Land Barons.” More recently, it is the center of a growing commercial airship industry.
Crup is a plantation-like farming village that has a deep divide between owners and the workers. There is a popular clinic here that is worth checking out.

Positioned as a poor yet peaceful place in the mountainous southern region of the land, Mile shows many types of unique farm animals. People sustain themselves through farming the land, and value freedom and autonomy above all. Even though they are the poorest, there is a spiritual connection to their homes and the beauty of the location itself lends to a majority of content people.
Located on the sea, Zima is one of the largest and most industrialized cities in Zariba. Its most important landmark is the National Hospital, the most advanced in the country.

This is the Capitol City of Zariba. Home to the offices of the Ministry of Health and where your journey to help Zariba begins! The Capitol sits on the main transportation line. With easy access to the glorious rail system, travelers can go from the Capitol to the most southern city, Zima, in only a few days time.

grading.description: Congratulations on exceeding your goals. The pilot test we conducted has shown significant increases in all three major indicators. We are confident that over the next three years, this program will continue to bear fruit.

The pilot test we ran showed some promising results. We have seen measurable increases in all three major indicators, especially in vaccinations. With proper implementation over the next three years, Facility Births and Quality of Care could rise to match it.

The results of our pilot test were mixed to say the least. Indicators have barely budged and are within the margins of error. We recommend re-evaluation of the context. A second attempt could yield a program with greater efficacy.

We ran a pilot test and somehow, your program has done more harm than good. Maybe RBF isn't the right answer after all. We strongly recommend re-evaluation of the context. More research and surveys should help. If this program is put into practice, the implementer will have their work cut out for them!

There are just not enough initiatives put into place for this program to move forward. Because of this, we weren't able to conduct an evaluation. I would recommend spending more time in the country in order to gather more information. Try visiting multiple cities and learning from many different people. You never know what you might learn.

text: Thank you again for coming all the way here. [[Your expertise]] is much appreciated. Our health system has been drastically underperforming despite concerted efforts. Our mortality rates for children under five are unacceptable.
Thank you again for all your help!

We have identified three indicators to address that could improve these numbers: Vaccinations, Facility Births, and Quality of Care. We have pushed facilities to improve on these indicators, but so far the results have been underwhelming. First and foremost, I recommend that you find a way to boost these key services and quality indicators.
unlocks_context: Facilities are not providing enough services. If they are incentivised to provide more, they probably will.

text: The Finance Minister looks at you intently with a [[serious expression]].
You have much to learn and I have spoken at length already.

"We have been using our usual methods of funding here," he says. "We have increased the budget for health care in each region year after year, but results have not increased to match it. This year, we will spend more than ever before. We need to try something new and more effective. That is why you are here. I have heard that facilities are struggling to meet basic needs for hiring and supplies. It is a risk, but perhaps we should give them the freedom to solve their own problems instead of making them dependant on us for all their needs."
unlocks_context: The Finance Minister suggests more autonomy is needed for health staff in the region.

text: Welcome again to Zariba! I hope you've had some time to yourself in the Capitol City to get your bearings, but of course, you are here to work. You'll be [[making a program]] that will transform our health system over the next four years, but to figure out what should be in that program, you will need to explore the country and [[talk to people]].
I still have more to tell you!

"You can use your notebook to keep track of where you have been, what you have learned, and what options seem to make sense for your program. The icon to open your notebook is on the lower left of your screen."

"In each area you visit, you will be able to talk to people just like you are talking to me, by clicking and spending conversation points. Your time in each city is limited though, so choose who you talk to wisely. I have taken the liberty of setting up a meeting with the Deputy Minister of Health, the Finance Minister, and the Regional Health Supervisor for the Highlands Region. It is starting now! They are on the other side of the talbe to your right. Click on them to talk."

The Regional Director speaks up. "I have been trying to improve the health system in the Highlands region for a few years now, but there are [[many obstacles]]. The main referral hospital is in Zima, which is far from the highlands and has its own logistical problems. If we want to improve the health of the people in Zariba, we need to start in the highlands, but even if these obstacles could be overcome, there is much [[confusion]]. The situation is not good, and we lag behind the rest of the country, and our neighbors," he says. "More than 80% of the people in the highlands live in extreme poverty, and cannot purchase even basic health services.
I still have more to tell you.

"Health professionals in the Highlands region could improve the services utilization and improve the health for the people that live there, but if the people in the catchment area cannot afford the services, what will it matter? We must find a way to make these service affordable."
unlocks_context: The Regional Director of Health Services for the Highlands says 80% of people live in extreme poverty.

text: When you ask about the confusion, he nods. "Those with little money also have little time to educate themselves on matters of health," he says. "If we are going to be implementing radical changes, I'm honestly not sure how people in the rural communities of the highlands will be able to keep up."
unlocks_context: It will be difficult to sensitize the population on changes, so good communication strategies will help.

text: The man extends a hand to shake and introduces himself. "Hello," he says, "I'm Dr. Maramuta. I run [[this clinic]], and I've worked with a number of others in the area. Times are tough these days, and our [[budget]] has been seriously strained."
Dr. Maramuta motions you over to him. "I have to meet with a patient soon, but I have a little more time to chat. What else can I help you with?"

"Things have been very tough. In the highlands, things are done differently. The situation is not ideal, and sometimes following protocol just takes extra time which is hard with so many patients. We don't have all the supplies we need, so sometimes the staff couldn't  follow protocols if they wanted to, and they don't seem to care, anyway. Between missing supplies and a lack of money, things are skimped on too often."
unlocks_context: Dr. Maramuta talked about not following protocols. This must be discouraged.

text: When you press him on budget strains, he backtracks a little bit. "It's not so much that we don't have any money, it's more that the budget has already been set by the Ministry of Health, and we don't have the ability to purchase the medicine and supplies we need. You understand."
unlocks_context: Dr. Maramuta in Crup needs autonomy to purchase supplies for his clinics.

text: You bring up Mr. Todd's claim that people travel long distances and receive no medicine. Dr. Maramuta nods. "This is sadly true, and also due to the budgeting issues I mentioned. It is a self-fulfilling prophecy. People tell their neighbors that there is no medicine, so people do not come here. Then since few people come, the Ministry adjusts our budget. Then when people do come, there is no medicine because of the budget lines we are given, and they spread the word. It will be hard to convince people that these problems have been solved."
unlocks_context: Dr. Maramuta says that clinics have a bad reputation. This needs to be countered.

text: He offers you a cigarette as you draw nearer, which you politely refuse. "Suit yourself," he says, taking another drag. He explains he has been working on the plantation for a few years now, and though the work is hard, the [[Advanced Equipment]] they use is always functional. "I just wish they paid us [[a bit more]]."
"You are still here?" the farmer asks. "Well then, what do you want to talk about?"

You ask about the expensive-looking machine he's leaning up against. "It's not mine," he says. "The Plantation owns this. They got a big grant from the government to modernize. Suits me fine, since I don't have to pick fruit out of thorns this way."
unlocks_context: A professor might have something to say about this.

text: You ask about the woman in Mile who takes pride in farming the land. "Pride is nice, but money is better. Even so, the pay does not go very far." He frowns, taking a puff from his cigarette. When you ask about affording health care, he laughs. "I can afford it, but I would never let my wife give birth in there; the traditional way is the best, at home. The clinic is fine, but I would rather save my money for something else, unless it's an emergency. You know?"
unlocks_context: Workers on the plantation in Crup believe delivering the traditional way is best.

text: You stand a little closer and are able to hear their conversation. "Damn arthritis," one says, grabbing at a tile. The other replies, "You should visit Kibari and see Mr. Todd. Best medicine man in Zariba!" You realize they haven't noticed your presence. Do you [[Keep listening]] or interrupt to [[ask about kibari]] or [[ask about Zima]].
"Excellent move," one says. "I have you on the run, now," replies the second. "Ouch... damn arthritis." "You need to see Mr. Todd."

You continue to listen in to their converation. "Mr. Todd, Mr. Todd. You always talk about him," the first man says, placing his piece on the board. "I might try it. The doctor at the clinic gave me some ointment and it did nothing. I went back two or three times and told him about the pain, but he kept giving me the same ointment. I asked for a referral to a hospital, but he refused."
unlocks_context: It sounds like the wrong medicine was prescribed in Crup. Doctors must follow protocol.

text: You interrupt their conversation to ask about Kibari. "People walk there. Mr. Todd's customers are very loyal. But if you do not wish to walk, a bus goes to Kibari twice a day..." the first man says. "It's your move," the other grumbles, growing impatient.
unlocks_context: You discovered a new route to Kibari.

text: "My favorite part of the lower region is the wonderful ride from here to Zima," the first man says. "You will want to jump on the commuter bus and hitch a ride down the highland highway. Say hi to Dr. Notega for me!"
unlocks_context: You discovered a new route to Zima.

text: The woman looks a bit exasperated, and not in the best health. When you ask her about her experience with the clinic, she offers a mostly [[negative account]]. "We are lucky to have a clinic nearby at all," she says. "But there are long waits here, and the clinic is very poor. I blame [[government incompetence]]."
She looks happy to see you again. Apparently she enjoyed sharing her experiences. "No one has ever asked me my opinions about something so important before."
"The rest would all be tolerable if the people at the hospitals and clinics were at least polite and helpful, but they are not. They treat us like a nuisance when they talk to us at all."
unlocks_context: Bad customer service discourages patients.

text: "The governor claims they are increasing the budget for health care and doing many great things for people in the highlands, but where are the results? I do not see them."
unlocks_context: If the government is not a competent, reliable regulator, an NGO might fill this role instead.

text: She greets you in a business-like way and introduces herself. "Yes, I do own this plantation," she says. "Over a hundred people work and live here. It wasn't easy, but I have worked hard and built a legacy for my [[sons]] to inherit when I'm gone. My oldest boy's wife, who is from Kibari, is pregnant. We have [[disagreements]] on where the child will be born."
The plantation owner nods to you. "Was there something else?"
"I have two sons. They were both born in the hospital in Zima, unlike the workers who want to deliver at home. I have a friend in Mile who is a midwife, you could ask her about it."
unlocks_context: A midwife might have more to say about this. Find her.

text: "In Zariba, it is customary that women give birth in their own homes with a traditional attendant in the room. My daughter in law does not want to travel to Valeria and does not want a midwife. It is frustrating." When you ask about whether her employees can afford the same care, she shrugs. "I would be willing to pay for my employees to deliver with a midwife, but they don't want to change their practices anyway."
unlocks_context: The plantation owner says that women give birth in their own homes, even when this is dangerous.

text: You mention the entrepreneurial loan from the government that Lydia told you about. The plantation owner nods. "We received one of those. This helped us upgrade the equipment, so we could make more profit here. My husband also lobbied parliament to improve road access throughout the highland region and these upgrades are now underway."

He pauses to speak with you, nervously keeping his birds in eyeshot, and occasionally redirecting them back to the flock. "Since you ask," he says, "I am a strong believer in traditional cures. They [[seem to work]], and they're [[easy to get]]."
"You are a curious one," the herder says.

"The clinic nearest to town never has any medicines, and I hear that some people travel for days to get to the hospital. Who wants to do that? You hear people die of negligence all the time in the hospital."
unlocks_context: The herder mentioned people are discouraged to travel.

text: He clutches his medallion. "This is said to protect me from fevers, which kill many people in this area. I have not gotten sick with a fever since I put it on. Hospitals on the other hand? Who even knows what happens in them?"
unlocks_context: People in Kibari believe strongly in traditional remedies. They are accustomed to the old ways of doing things.

text: A look of suspicion comes over his face for a moment, but it is quickly replaced with the same smile from before. "Greetings!" he says. "Yes, it is true. I am Mr. Todd." You recognize the name. "I would not claim to be the [[best medicine man]] in Zariba, but if that is what they say, that is [[what they say]]!" He gives you a knowing nod. "As for you, I know who you are. You're here working with the Ministry, coming to promote their useless clinics."
Mr. Todd smirks at you as you return. "Still here, hmm? What more do you want me to say?"

He chuckles. "People come to me because I am already a part of their lives. Part of their community! The hospitals and clinics you want people to visit are not good. The nurses and doctors treat you like a stranger. No, like an interloper. An annoyance. They do not care about people like I do. My patients are always satisfied."
unlocks_context: If facility staff are not treating patients well, lets incentivise them based on improved patient satisfaction.

text: You press, and ask him what else people are saying. "People say lots of things," he replies. "For instance, those nasty rumors about what else has been going on in the hospitals. I heard some folks saying they believe hospitals are a trick to take our money and make us sicker! I don't know how those get started. People say what they say," he reiterates.
unlocks_context: There seems to be misinformation about hospitals, dissuading people from using them. An information campaign could counter this.

text: "That's right! I say useless. Why would a person travel to see a doctor who can't even give them medicine? Ask your doctors that. Meanwhile, you come to me, you leave with medicine in hand. Even better, my cures are distributed far and wide."
unlocks_context: Doctors are not providing medicine? Find out why at the clinic in Crup.

text: "Folks around here call me Nomad. Care to hear a song?" His light fingers pluck out a pleasant tune. When his song ends, he looks at you [[expectantly]].
Good luck on your journey!

You drop a few appreciative coins into his hat, and he thanks you. "And here's a tip for you. If you're interested in medicine, make your way to Zima for sure. But talk to Dr. Maramuta at the clinic in Crup before you leave Zariba. Most people in the highlands never see the inside of a hospital, but clinics are pretty common."
"I work at a clinic nearby," she says. You wonder what it is like to [[work in her clinic]], so hear to Kibari, and about the [availability of supplies]] there.
Did you have more to ask me?

She responds, "I am frequently running out of supplies, the medical supply department in the capitol is never sending me the supplies I am requesting in a timely manner. The buffer drug stock gets finished every time before getting the new supplies. For example, I run out of vaccines and syringes all the time. I am sure you heard of the recent measles outbreak? I also do not have basic medicines and supplies to treat patients. If I had the resources I could buy the supplies I need here in Kibari."
unlocks_context: If the nurse aid had the resources, she could buy supplies locally.

text: "I see many patients, but it is also very frustrating as I can not be in the clinic all day. I have to work two jobs to make ends meet for my family as a nurse aid in the government health system. I do not get paid enough. Incentives would help me spend more time delivering services."
unlocks_context: Incentives for the nurse aid enables her to spend more time in the clinic, rather than working another job.

text: He extends a hand for you to shake as you come nearer. When you ask him what he thinks about hospitals, he seems mostly positive on them. "I would go to a hospital if something was wrong with me," he says. "But I'm healthy, thank goodness. A lot of other people seem to [[distrust]] the hospitals though, especially in [[this area]]."
The teen waves as you draw nearer. "I was wondering if I would see you again. Something else you want to talk about?"

"Well," he says, "It is simple enough. The medicine is foreign. The hospitals are far away, and when you get there, you are treated by strangers. It is just unfamiliar, and people distrust what is not familiar. Perhaps if these hospitals hired more people from our communities, that would help. People might be more willing to go to them if they could count on seeing friendly faces. And besides, we could use the work around here."
unlocks_context: Hiring nurses from local communities could encourage people to visit facilities.

text: "You must know where you are. We are in the heart of the highlands. People here are used to doing things the old way. That means Mr. Todd." He points to the lavish domicile further along the road where a well-dressed man stands.
unlocks_context: People are ingrained in the old ways of doing things. You have to work hard to promote a new way of working.

text: When you approach him, his eyes light up. "What can I do for you?" he asks. "Anything you need, I have it." You buy some sweets from him out of politeness, and after that he seems happy to share what he knows about the area. "The nearest cities to here are [[Crup]] and [[Mile]]. Both easy enough to get to. I'm actually on my way to [[Zima]].
"Anything else you need?" he asks, watching as you approach.

You ask about Mile, and he offers some advice. "In Mile, no one has any money at all, but it is on the route to the capitol city, so I pass through from time to time. If you want to get there, just hop on one of the produce trucks that makes the rounds from here to there. They leave pretty frequently."
unlocks_context: You discovered a new route to Mile.

text: "The people from Crup," he says, "Are poor, except for the plantation owners. They can only afford basic things. There is a clinic there, though. If you want to go there, there is a bus that departs in the mornings and evenings."
unlocks_context: You discovered a new route to Crup.

text: "I'm headed there soon. Nice city. Port town. With a large hospital, too. You can tag along with me and I'll show you the way."
unlocks_context: You discovered a new route to Zima.

text: He introduces himself enthusiastically and tells you about his work studying political science and the old Zariban empire. His friendly demeanor shifts into annoyance as he speaks about his need to get to [[Mile]] and sighs as he holds up a picture of the [[Prime Minister]] on the front page of his paper.
The professor closes the window on his tablet and looks you square in the eye. "Back to continue our conversation?"

You ask him about Mile: "I have not been down that far south in decades but I hear the life hasn't changed much. Good people who still remember life before the current regime took power." He indicates the Prime Minister's photo as he speaks. "You can take the train through Mile into Zima, though the tracks have been terrible for years."
unlocks_context: Find someone in Mile who has traveled. They can confirm this...

text: As soon as you say the words 'prime minister' his eyes grow wide and he puts down his paper. "You know, ever since the new government took power, the trains have gotten worse and worse. They should be investing in transport instead of inviting foreign companies into the country to steal our natural resources." He eyes you appraisingly before continuing. "I will tell you this, the government is corrupt and incompetent. They are not respected in the highlands, where they still remember the old regime. They can't keep the trains running, and they won't be in power for long."
unlocks_context: The government might not be a strong partner, an NGO might be needed to make sure services are delivered.

text: You bring up the farm bill you learned about in Crup. "You mean the massive bribe given to landowners out of the people's pocket? Just more proof that this government needs to buy support. It is like the papers say; the Prime Minister is far more interested in pleasing foreigners than helping his own people." You do not argue, but it strikes you that he is contradicting himself.

After a few attempts of getting her attention, she tells you how she has been waiting for hours for the next train out of the station. "There have been two trains heading to Mile that have already been [[canceled]]!" Flustered, she mutters under her breath about being late to meet [[her friend]]."
She's finished with her phone call now, and it's easy to get her attention again.

She nods, looking unhappy. "Unfortunately, this happens all too often. The train has been the main way both people and goods move through the country for longer than I can remember. But it is unreliable."
unlocks_context: A traveler says that goods move by train, but the train is unreliable. A private company could avoid this problem.

text: You learn she is attempting to head to Zima, the southern city on the water, to visit her friend Doctor Notega at the hospital there. "We are very close, and since he has been frustrated with his job, I want to help him have a little fun for a few days. Apparently he has not been receiving supplies, or so he says. If you go there, ask him, and I am  sure he will tell you all about it."
unlocks_context: Doctor Notega in Zima will know more about this.

text: "Fresh fruit!" she calls as you approach. "Only the best, grown by local [[farmers]]. Try the berries! They are a [[Valerian]] favorite." She hands you a sample. "No charge," she says.
The woman looks at you with recognition and offers a wave as you return. "Can I help you with something else?"

You ask about the farmers who grew the fruit. "Me and my neighbors spend our time working on the land so that we can harvest the fruit. I come to the city so I can sell fruit to make ends meet and support my family. I barely scrape by, but I make my own way."
unlocks_context: People like the fruit farmers can't afford services, so vouchers may be necessary.

text: You ask about Valeria. "Valeria never used to be part of Zariba, but now that we have road access there is a whole new market! The airship port is somthing you wont want to miss. A bus leaves for Valeria every hour until sunset."
unlocks_context: You have discovered a route to Valeria

text: "You are looking ill, my friend!" he says to you by way of greeting. "We have the cure for whatever ails you. All of our products are 100% derived from the land itself, and we never use any ingredients of foreign origin. Our medicine is the only cure that has been proven by centuries of practice here in Zariba. We have an office in [[Kibari]], so all our products are checked for authenticity by [[Mr. Todd]] himself!"
"Was there something else you needed?" the Merchant asks. "Whatever you need, I have it!"

You approach the man and ask about Kibari: "Kibari is the heart of the highlands, and the center of commerce and traditional knowledge for the nation. From Kibari, the whole nation is wide open to you. It is easy enough to get to. Just hitch a ride with one of the local farm transports. They come and go every day."
unlocks_context: You've discovered a new route to Kibari.

text: As soon as you mention Mr. Todd the medicine merchant's face lights up. "I might be a bit biased, but that man is everything for the local region. He is a genius who has built a business from the ground up! Literally! Everyone loves Mr. Todd. You need to meet him. I am sure one conversation with him will change all your thoughts on foreign medicine!"
unlocks_context: Mr. Todd in Kibari will have more to say about this.

text: You lean a little closer and realize they are two prominent NGO Managers. They reference the difficulty they have been having [[incentivizing service providers]] to vaccinate more children. They're talking about [[an epidemic]] that is apparently spreading.
They're still talking, but they seem aware that you're nearby. You're beginning to feel a little awkward.

"How has your organization dealt with the growing gap in vaccination rates?" one women says to the other. The other woman responds proudly, "Our program greatly improved the number of children vaccinated in the north. It incentivized the providers to improve quality of care instead of increasing only the quantity of services. This worked especially well when we emphasized protocol and therapeutic guidelines."
unlocks_context: NGO managers suggested it is important to incentivize providers to follow protocols and therapeutic guidelines.

text: "Have you heard? In the Highlands, access to services is limited and people do not value the importance of preventive services like vaccinations. Instead they only go to the clinic when they are sick." The first woman says this with a slight agitation. The second woman chimes in "They should be utilizing outreach in this region and detecting epidemic casess. In the north, this has been is crucial to helping the area get back on its feet."
unlocks_context: Bringing healthcare workers directly to communities and providing services like vaccinations can prevent an epidemic.

text: As you step closer, she stops what she is doing and looks at you with some suspicion. "Not that I am not thankful for an excuse to rest and talk," she says, "but I have a lot of work to do. This harvest will feed my [[family]], and others in the village." There is a hint of [[pride]] in her voice.
The farm worker hums to herself. When she sees you approach, she pauses. "Back again?"

"I have two sons and a daughter, a husband and a brother," she explains. When you ask about their health care, particularly whether her children have been immunized, she shrugs, looking a little guilty. "I barely have time to do what needs doing here, you know? Between doing my work and taking care of basic needs, who has time to think about health care, let alone visit a clinic? Taking care of basics like food and water, and a roof that does not leak is far more important. I have heard that the government is introducing a welfare program for people like me. That will help, but I still don't see the purpose of going to a health facility to vaccinate my children when they are not sick."
unlocks_context: People are concerned with leaking roofs. An organized social welfare scheme could make visiting health services a condition of the program.

text: "I guess I am proud of it," she smiles. "My family has farmed this land for generations. Soon my children will be old enough to contribute, and carry our family on to the next generation. This makes me very happy. It's not just about feeding ourselves. This isn't some plantation like Crup. We work for ourselves here and value the way that we connect with the land as we have done for generations."
unlocks_context: Ask a farm worker in Crup for another perspective on this.

text: When you give her the opportunity, she is all too happy to vent. She explains that she is a [[midwife]], and that she just had a job interview at the hospital in Zima. "Or at least I [[thought I did]]."
She looks frustrated and ready to continue venting. "I will tell you something else."

She is clearly still upset about what happened at the hospital as she tells you the story in an angry tone. "I traveled more than a day to get there, and did the entire interview, only to be told that suddenly there were no resources available to hire me! The hospital administrator said she would love to have me on their staff, but bureaucrats in the capitol suddenly decided there was no budget for that."
unlocks_context: Ask the Hospital Administrator in Zima more about this.

text: She scoffs. "Skilled midwives such as myself who can travel are very hard to come by, and very in demand these days, since most women won't travel long distances to give birth. I can't believe they would not hire me. I could even be hired here in Mile, and that would save the lives of many mothers and babies."
unlocks_context: A budget for outreach staff is necessary, according to the midwife in Mile.

text: You ask the midwife about what the plantation owner said. "Yes, that is true. Women do prefer to give birth at home, and I don't see that changing any time soon. People don't like being told they are wrong. My advice is to focus on improving health services and spreading the word, not attacking old customs."

He greets you with a friendly nod. "I have been just about everywhere in this country, you know? I travel here and there, play my harp, make enough money for a meal, and then on to the next place! The people here are poor. Can't give me much coin for my time, but that just means they need music the most. So I always stop in this town on my way to the next destination. What they lack in money they more than make up for in hospitality and spirit. Good cooks, too!"

He does not seem particularly bothered by your presence, and puts the magazine on his lap to speak with you. After a few minutes of idle conversation, he volunteers a little more about his past. "I was not from here originally," he says. "I came here as a refugee many years ago, back during the old regime. It was a very [[difficult journey]]." A frown spreads across his face. "My village was destroyed by a [[landslide]] during a rain storm. It will never be rebuilt. The government doesn't want to spend money on this because they happen so often, so people just move."
He looks up from his magazine to greet you. "Nice to see you again. Did you want to discuss something with me?"

"Some people miss the old regime," he says, "They were very nationalistic, but they never did anything for me, you know? I have lived through a lot, and democracy seems much better than the alternative." He fans himself with the news magazine and finishes his thought. "Some people disagree, and wish they could go back. But most don't care. I would ignore the nationalist claptrap that some spout."

"It was so terrible," he says. "Unless you have seen one, it is hard to describe. The entire village was just gone. Many people died. I lost family members. I feel lucky that I was able to make it here, and was accepted and given hospitality. There were some NGOs that helped refugees settle, as people here do not have much. If it weren't for them, I don't know how I could have survived."
unlocks_context: The refugee in Mile talked about landslides. An outside organization might be better equipped to cope.

text: He nods and explains how travel is very difficult unless you can afford to buy a train ticket. "And few can! If you can't afford a ticket, you must walk along the tracks, and it is very dangerous, takes days of walking. Recently, someone died making the trip to Zima, and now no one even tries it unless they are desperate, you know? Just last month, a woman died giving birth and she couldn't make it to the hospital in time. Later, the husband was told that if the woman had come for recommended care visits, the issue could have been detected and prevented."
unlocks_context: It is difficult to travel, according to the refugee in Mile. Bringing Outreach staff to villages may be necessary.

text: "Oh, hello," the woman says. "This airship port wasn't here the last time I came to this town, so it's a little confusing. We were visiting here for a little bit. My [[grandson]] has been sick for a long time, and he always wanted to see the sand palaces. After I convinced that terrible doctor to write me a [[prescription]] the little guy is finally up to travelling."
"Oh, hello again. What else do you want to chat about?"

When you inquire about the health of her grandson, she seems a little unsure. "I think he's vaccinated," she says, "but I don't really care for these hospitals. The nurse there was rude to me. He made me feel unwelcome and I had to argue with a doctor about getting a prescription for my little one."
unlocks_context: The Grandmother in Valeria thinks the nurses are rude.

text: "I do not remember exactly what the doctor said, but he kept saying that he did not need antibiotics. When I finally got him to write me a prescription, I felt like he wrote it just to shut me up. He did not seem to care, you know?"
unlocks_context: Doctors are writing prescriptions to please patients, not based on solid medical reasons.

text: She seems very at ease as you approach, and introduces herself as Lydia, an airship pilot. "These airships are pretty new, so not many people can fly one. This one here is [[mine]]," she says with some pride, pointing to a floating craft. "I'm about to depart on a [[personal trip]] to [[Zima]], and I'm just going through my flight checklist."
"I am about to head out. Was there something else you wanted to talk about?"
You ask about Zima. "I do have room for a passenger if you are headed that way..."
unlocks_context: You discovered a new route to Zima.

text: You ask how she was able to afford the airship, and she tells you about an entrepreneurial loan she received from the government last year. "I could not have afforded it otherwise. They do a lot of good in this region. They have my vote."
unlocks_context: Are many people being helped by the government? Ask the plantation owner in Crup.

text: "I am actually three months pregnant today," she offers, "and I have an appointment with Dr. Notega in Zima. If I'm being honest, I wouldn't trust any other facility for this. The clinics don't seem to have the resources and staff do not seem to be very proactive to provide services. There used to be a good clinic in Valeria that recently burned down."
unlocks_context: If clinics lack resources to deliver facility births, and staffs are not motivated, incentives for this service may be needed.

text: "Funny seeing you here" the harper says. "I have been everywhere in this country. This part of Zariba is probably the richest. Land Barons have been building palaces out of sand for hundreds of years here. Not sure how they get the sand to hold together, but it seeing is believing. The airships are new, though. Got to change with the times."
The two are having a conversation about where they'd like to go this weekend, and whether to take an airship ride or not. [[Listen]] [[Interrupt]]
The twins are still chatting with each other. "I can't wait to get out of here. This airship dock isn't my idea of fun."
"I wish Lydia was flying to the capitol instead of Zima. Who cares about some boring hospital? The nightclub in that city is so over." "Her airship is so tiny anyway. We barely fit," the other says.
unlocks_context: You discovered a new route to Zima.

text: They stare at you for a moment when you approach, then ask who you are. When you explain yourself, they are happy to share their opinions on Zariba's health care system. "The highlands are where all the poor people live," the brother says. "Obviously," his sister interrupts. "Everyone knows that. We were both born here in Valeria. No one likes to go to those hospitals in the Highlands. They're so run-down and uninviting." "I've been in one. They just feel dirty, and they smell. And the staff seem very uninterested," the brother agrees. "That's why no one wants to go to them."
unlocks_context: The twins in Valeria say that people avoid the hospitals because they look run-down.

text: At first, he seems too engrossed in the chart to devote his full attention to you, but once you introduce yourself, he puts it down and apologizes. "I wish I had time for a formal sit down with you," he says, "but time is tight around here. I will try to share as much as I can. This hospital works very well [[for the rich]], since they can afford whatever tests and procedures we order, but [[poor people]] tend to shy away from us, which is a shame."
Dr. Notega seems a little overwhelmed, but he pauses in his work to talk to you. "Anything else you want to know? I am happy to talk while I have a little time."

You ask more about the poor people of the highlands and he gives a frustrated shrug. "The majority of people in the highlands have no money. They can not afford basic care like deliveries. Even if they could, I am not sure they would purchase it."
unlocks_context: Dr. Notega says only the rich can afford to deliver in his hospital.

text: "I admit, we mainly provide services for our affluent customers. We deliver quality services, so running a hospital is expensive. If the government were incentivizing us to deliver the same services for the poor, we would be able to do so."
unlocks_context: At the hospital, services that 'keep the lights on' are prescribed. We could incentivise the services we need delivered.

text: You ask about the supply issues his friend told you about back in the train station. "Yes, there are serious supply issues, but the problem is not the train. It is our budget. The hospital administrator can tell you all about this, I am sure."

You strike up a conversation with the traveler, and she explains that she is investigating the mining industry in [[West Zariba]] for her company. "It is a [[long journey]] that goes through the highlands."
"My car is leaving soon," she says. "So make it quick."

She looks anxious. "I will not be taking the train. Instead, I am taking a private motor car. I am afraid of trains. I leave in a few hours, bound for Kibari, which I hear is the center of the Zariban Highlands. I guess it is kind of exciting."
unlocks_context: You've discovered a new route to Kibari.

text: She's happy to tell you about West Zariba. "It is a long way from the highlands," she says. "Because of international interest in natural resources, this area has been invested in heavily by the Zariban Government. They are quite capable of building infrastructure when they are motivated to do so."

She notices you, and rises to shake your hand. "Very pleased to meet you. I have been expecting you, actually," she says. She begins a frank explanation of the hospital's challenges. "The worst thing has been a lack of supplies. We are frequently out of stock on basic things due to [[budget constraints]]. This has a [[trickle-down effect]] on many other hospital functions."
The hospital administrator looks frustrated. She tugs on her hair as she pores over some document. When she sees you again, she looks up. "Oh, I thought you had left. What else can I tell you?"

"The root cause of the constraints is simple bureaucracy. How we spend our budget is determined by a ministry bureaucrat in the capitol city who has no idea what our actual needs are. If we had the autonomy to allocate and spend our budget, the supply issue would go away."
unlocks_context: The hospital administrator says she lacks the autonomy to purchase needed supplies.

text: "When we do not have the proper supplies, it looks bad to the patients, and we lose face. Not only that, the lack of basic supplies begins to wear on my staff. I am aware of some attitude problems. All of this is not conducive to treating patients."
unlocks_context: Stressed staff have 'attitude problems' according to the hospital administrator.

unlockable_dialogue_hospital_administrat.display_name: Ask about the midwife in Mile
text: You bring up the midwife you met in Mile, and the administrator nods. "The same problem, as we do not have the autonomy to allocate the budget that we had requested for a midwife to be hired. At the central level, they did not feel this was important, so I had to turn away a qualified, needed worker."
unlocks_context: In Zima's hospital, midwives are needed but they lack the autonomy to hire them.

text: Once you get him talking, the nurse seems almost relieved to have someone to complain to. "I work harder than anyone in this facility, but compared to the doctors, I get paid practically nothing! I deal with [[angry people]] every day. He just writes [[prescriptions]]."
The nurse motions for you to come back over to him. "Listen to me, and I will tell you how things really are," he says.

The tall nurse crosses his arms. "They get angry when I tell them we don't have the medicines. When the pharmacy doesn't have the drugs, they blame me and then ask stupid questions! I get tired of it."
unlocks_context: Nurses are clearly over-stressed, and provide poor service.

text: "Lucky for the doctors, they can just write the prescriptions. I have seen antibiotics prescribed for viruses, or even for nothing at all, just because it is the only medicine we always have in stock."
unlocks_context: According to the nurse, doctors are prescribing medicine for the wrong reasons.

text: She seems surprised when you sit down to talk with her. She explains that it cost her [[a lot of money]] to get here, but it was necessary since her headaches do not go away, and she wanted to get her grandson vaccinated.
"Still waiting!" she says as you approach. "Did you want to talk about something else?"
"Would you believe it? The train cost me more than the medicine!"
unlocks_context: A patient in Zima complained it is expensive to travel.

text: "Most of my neighbors cannot afford even simple health services like vaccinations or doctors appointments."
unlocks_context: Most people cannot afford services, according to a patient.

prompt_year_1: Thank you for joining us for the end of year meeting. It seems like your program implementation is going smoothly, yes? That said, we would like to know if you need anything approved through us to make the program run more efficiently. It seems like your program is running quite well, but there is always opportunity for slight modification.
prompt_year_2: You've made it to the end of year two. I hope you are checking your indicators and making sure the RBF program is running smoothly. Is there anything you need from us? If the new Clinic Manager is not working out we can make internal adjustments.

problems.name: Government Overreach on Verification
problems.initiating_dialogue: The ministry has asked us to send copies of all our reports to them for verification. I thought that was supposed to stop and we would only send reports to the third party verifier? I guess I'm still a little confused.

dep_minister_of_health.dialogue: We are very interested in making sure the providers are doing what they say, and we have the staff available to review, so why not?

feedback.clarify_separation_of_functions_1: All right, I understand. I'll inform the staff here.

director_regional_health_services.dialogue: I know the Minister of Health fairly well, and I can tell you that things go more smoothly if you're cooperative.

coach.dialogue: Duplicating efforts seems to be hampering the health providers. I'd clarify everyone's roles for them.

third_party_verifier.dialogue: I didn't know about this. If the Ministry is doubling our verification efforts, it could prove very confusing to the providers.

community_verifier.dialogue: As long as these things get verified, that's all that matters to me.

clinic_manager.dialogue: Honestly, we've been ignoring the ministry's requests. We've got too much actual work to worry about.

problems.name: Bad Record Keeping
problems.initiating_dialogue: The Clinic submitted their reports on indicator performance, but there appear to be some inconsistencies. When we asked to see their records, they could not supply them.

dep_minister_of_health.dialogue: If they are not following the rules, they should not be paid. A penalty may also be in order.

director_regional_health_services.dialogue: All providers in my region should know the requirements for keeping records. Something must be wrong. I'd talk to them.

coach.dialogue: I don't know why they aren't keeping records. When I spoke with them last, they said everything was fine and they didn't want my help.

feedback.help_build_capacity_1: I will strengthen on the spot training during the verification for them to see the mistakes they are making.

community_verifier.dialogue: My team has had no issue keeping records. I wonder what the issue is at the clinics?

clinic_manager.dialogue: I'm surprised, I thought the reports we submitted were correct. It would be really helpful if someone could explain the mistakes we are making.

feedback.hold_payment_1: We will improve things next quarter.
feedback.sanctions_1: We can hardly pay staff as it is! Many patients will go untreated because of this.

hospital_administrator.dialogue: Perhaps they just need some more time to get used to all of this. This is all new. Cut them some slack this once, and they'll figure it out as we go.

problems.name: Poor Management
problems.initiating_dialogue: I have been reviewing the Hospital's business plan with the administrator, and they do not seem to manage their funds very well. They are operating at a loss, even with our payments. It's because of unwise spending habits.

dep_minister_of_health.dialogue: There are other health providers in the region we could use. This is the largest, but it doesn't mean it is the best.

director_regional_health_services.dialogue: The staff at the hospital have been slow to adapt to new practices.

feedback.terminate_contract_effective_end_of_year: It seems early to terminate their contract, but let's review at year's end. In the meantime, I will be observing and offering ways to improve.

third_party_verifier.dialogue: It seems this hospital has not been able to increase their performance very well.

community_verifier.dialogue: I would talk directly to them if I were you.

clinic_manager.dialogue: I don't really have time to talk about this right now. Sorry.

hospital_administrator.dialogue: We're doing our best here.  There are many intricacies to the business plan, and not everyone on my staff understands them. I'm sure they'll get used to it soon, though.

feedback.warning_and_retraining_1: Do you really think this is necessary?

problems.name: Avoiding Responsibility
problems.initiating_dialogue: I requested a meeting with the Clinic Manager recently to go over practices for making information on their performance publicly available. They keep rescheduling and canceling, but the performance score makes it clear that they are not performing on this and losing out.

dep_minister_of_health.dialogue: I don't think this is a big issue, and we have other more urgent things to worry about.

director_regional_health_services.dialogue: I have experienced similar problems with this provider. It is hard to schedule their time. Transparency to the community is a key priority to ensure in their next business plan.

feedback.take_no_further_action_1: I'm sure I'll have some time next quarter once our busiest time dies down.

third_party_verifier.dialogue: Community transparency does not seem to be high on their agenda, so, yes, they are performing low on their quality score.

community_verifier.dialogue: This is a little outside of my purview.

clinic_manager.dialogue: I think you underestimate just how busy we have been with outreach and patient care. We are not a large staff, and our time is very precious. Maybe next quarter things will be slower and we can focus on this.

feedback.revise_business_plan_to_include_transpar: Hopefully things will be less busy so we can focus on that. If it can bring in more resources, then it's worth exploring.

hospital_administrator.dialogue: I've observed the clinics we're talking about a number of times, and there's never enough time and money to go around. They are just not interested.

problems.name: Mismanagement
problems.initiating_dialogue: I was visiting the hospital for my mentoring visit, and they still don't have a balanced budget or expenditure. The business plan has clear guidelines on this and the Administrator is not sticking to them.

dep_minister_of_health.dialogue: It sounds like funds have gone missing.

director_regional_health_services.dialogue: Have you considered that there is a flaw in the business plan? If the Hospital Administrator is straying from it so often, it might need to be reevaluated.

feedback.retraining_on_use_of_financial_tools: I hope the Hospital Administrator will see its importance. I'll make some time this week for a retraining session and try to drill down on exactly how these tools should be used.

third_party_verifier.dialogue: If I had to guess, I would say this is simple mismanagement, nothing fraudulent.

community_verifier.dialogue: I'm not really sure. I have never even been to the hospital!

clinic_manager.dialogue: When was the last time the hospital revised the business plan?

hospital_administrator.dialogue: We need to spend money where it's needed, and as the administrator of this hospital, I know where it is needed. That was the purpose of granting us autonomy in the first place.

feedback.sanctions_17: I will do my best, but I'm really worried things are going to start breaking down soon.
feedback.audit_2: Very well, I'll clear some time. I'm sure you won't find anything wrong with our books.

problems.name: Lack of Transparency
problems.initiating_dialogue: There is an ongoing issue with the Clinic Manager. They are small things, but since they have been having issues with record keeping, I looked more closely and found some forms that seem like exact duplicates of others.

dep_minister_of_health.dialogue: This is very distressing. I urge you to deal with this harshly.

director_regional_health_services.dialogue: This is troubling to hear. I may begin looking into other providers for you to contract next year.

coach.dialogue: This is a big deal. If these records are not accurate, we have no way of measuring progress. We need to send a very clear message. Unvalidated reports cannot be paid.

feedback.warning_3: I'll warn them. Hopefully we will see some improvement next quarter.

community_verifier.dialogue: That sounds pretty suspicious.

clinic_manager.dialogue: I will direct my staff to start keeping better records. I can talk to them again and stress its importance.

feedback.mild_sanctions: Our budget has been wearing thin as it is! I will have to fire staff because of this.
feedback.terminate_contract: This is a disaster! For such a small error?

hospital_administrator.dialogue: Don't go too hard on them. These clinics do good work.

problems.name: Inconsistent Indicators
problems.initiating_dialogue: We are seeing some indicators rise while others stay stagnant. Hospital births are barely rising, though checkups and vaccination rates are improving. We need to see all indicators rising!

director_regional_health_services.dialogue: I suggest hiring more outreach staff to operate in facilities near these settlements.

feedback.hire_more_outreach_staff: This makes a good deal of sense to me.

coach.dialogue: We've tried many strategies to improve stagnant indicators. Perhaps the indicators need to be reviewed at the end of the year?

feedback.review_indicators_at_end_of_year: It might make sense to revise goals down, or at the very least, perform another survey to make sure our population estimates were correct.

third_party_verifier.dialogue: Are you concerned about fraud? I haven't seen direct evidence of it.

community_verifier.dialogue: People here are still reluctant to travel to facilities.

clinic_manager.dialogue: I admit, we haven't seen as many facility births as we'd like. We're doing everything we can to change that.

feedback.broaden_services: I am sure this will help us meet our goals and raise indicators even though it changes the plan.

hospital_administrator.dialogue: Vaccinations are easier to manage. Births take more planning. More resources are likely required to make this work.

feedback.raise_incentives_for_facility_births: That will make this a good deal easier for us.

problems.name: Budget Lines
problems.initiating_dialogue: I received a memo today about policy guidance and the new national health budget. The ministry has released new purchasing guidelines for all providers, but that limits our autonomy. This is bad news for us.

dep_minister_of_health.dialogue: Our auditors have found mismanagement of funds. The providers need strict guidelines to provide the necessary services, and use the funds appropriately.

feedback.clarify_separation_of_functions: This revision to the procurement guideline is within the scope of regulation, which is my role. But if you think it's essential for the providers to keep autonomy, we will step back on this.

director_regional_health_services.dialogue: If the Ministry is claiming this is necessary, I would take it seriously. A compromise might be to re-work the RBF Manual, and training with Ministry oversight.

coach.dialogue: I have found some mismanagement of funds in the past as well, but appropriate actions were taken. We are supposed to be granting autonomy. Also, remember that the providers are paid for the services already provided.

feedback.comply_with_ministry_request: I don't believe this is the best option, but if you insist...

third_party_verifier.dialogue: We are verifying the result and ensure that the providers get paid accurately. So why take away their autonomy?

community_verifier.dialogue: I don't understand the need for these new guidelines, but then again, I am not working in the hospital.

clinic_manager.dialogue: I need to be able to purchase whatever is needed. This is a return to the bad old days, with many delays in receiving supplies from the central level, and I can't agree with it.

feedback.rework_rbf_manual_and_retrain: I don't believe this will be constructive, but I'm willing to try.

problems.name: Wrong Numbers
problems.initiating_dialogue: I have been reviewing the Clinic's records, and they do not check out. These problems with their numbers have been going on for two years now.

dep_minister_of_health.dialogue: If needed, we could end the contract. Let's do some serious investigation into if this is necessary.

director_regional_health_services.dialogue: I've had some communication issues with the Clinic Manager in the past, but I believe he is honest. You should talk to him directly to see what the problem is.

coach.dialogue: This has been going on for several years now. I'd recommend to sanction.

community_verifier.dialogue: The sample I surveyed does not align with the numbers you say they reported. Very suspicious.

hospital_administrator.dialogue: I don't think the clinic should get preferential treatment over my hospital. Treat them just as you would treat us.

clinic_manager.dialogue: I have some new staff, maybe they are confused about what to report? Frankly, I myself have been confused at times!

feedback.hold_meeting_to_retrain_on_reporting_pra: I think that will probably help. Let me know when works for you and I'll clear some time for a meeting.
feedback.warning_5: I'll talk to my staff and try to settle this.
feedback.sanctions_3: I just put in orders for new equipment. Now I won't be able to afford to pay for them. I think you are talking this too far. It was an honest mistake of newly employed staff.

problems.name: More Transparency
problems.initiating_dialogue: I was visiting one of the clinics for my mentoring visit and I was unhappy with their transparency. They do not display their performance indicators, or even contact details for the public in an emergency. The community representatives are also complaining that the clinics haven't held a single meeting with the Health Facility Management Committee.

dep_minister_of_health.dialogue: I was under the impression that the program required transparency.

director_regional_health_services.dialogue: This has gone far enough. I will start looking for other providers.

feedback.terminate_contract_at_end_of_year_3: I will warn them that their contract is in danger of being terminated at the end of the year.
feedback.capacity_building: I feel like I've been doing this for a year already, but let's see if we can't make some progress

third_party_verifier.dialogue: Their record keeping has been spotty as well, though it has improved since last year.

community_verifier.dialogue: I would talk to the provider directly on this matter.

clinic_manager.dialogue: We are simply over worked here, and have little time for meetings when our patients are sick and already have long waits. The Coach should be helping us build capacity, not draining our capacity.

feedback.warning_4: I'll try to make my staff more available next time.

hospital_administrator.dialogue: I haven't been having this problem, so I'm not sure what to tell you.

problems.name: Poor Quality Indicator Scores
problems.initiating_dialogue: Hey, the third party verifier just came to assess our quality score, but I disagree with the assessment results. Given the amount of strain we are under, I believe we need to be granted some leeway in order to serve patients.

dep_minister_of_health.dialogue: Quality of care is important insofar as it enables better and more services to be delivered.

director_regional_health_services.dialogue: I recognize that their job is difficult, but quality of care is one of the indicators we are working to improve.

coach.dialogue: Quality of care is not something we should grant leeway on. It is crucially important, but if they are under such strain, they may require extra staff.

Feedback.review_the_inspection: Thank you! I think you'll find our quality is sufficient.

third_party_verifier.dialogue: They scored poorly, plain and simple. A review is not necessary.

community_verifier.dialogue: These are small clinics, with very little operating budget. Denying payment will cause immediate harm to the community.

Feedback.revise_business_plan_10: I would appreciate some support from the coach to figure out how we can improve things here.
Feedback.deny_review: If you aren't going to take me seriously, how can I have faith in this system?

hospital_administrator.dialogue: I can tell you it is painful to lose out in payment because of the quality score when things get busy. What harm is there in reviewing the inspection?

problems.name: Over Capacity
problems.initiating_dialogue: We've seen some great improvements over the past three years, but now the hospital is almost at capacity. We might need to expand hiring to keep up with demand.

dep_minister_of_health.dialogue: It's great news that they've managed to improve their performance so much.

coach.dialogue: I agree they are doing very well, and they may need more resources, but why don't you leave it to the provider to decide they want to hire more staff? In line with their autonomy, I mean.

feedback.expand_hiring_of_hospital_staff: We gave the providers autonomy to decide how to best improve performance, are you sure this is the best solution? Shouldn't they decide?

third_party_verifier.dialogue: This is a good problem to have.

community_verifier.dialogue: The people in my most recent sample have been happy with the services they received, but did report long waits.

clinic_manager.dialogue: I'd love to have more staff too. Or is this just for the hospital? Wouldn't it be better if you gave us the money and let us decide how to get the best results?

feedback.increase_incentives_for_all_facilities: Thank you, this is fantastic news, I look forward to performing even better.

hospital_administrator.dialogue: I am worried about on-boarding and managing many new people. Why don't you just give us more resources so we can decide whether to reward existing staff or to hire new people?

feedback.increase_incentives_to_hospital: This is great, now I can really address older problems and make this a star-performing hospital.

problems.name: Checkup Overload
problems.initiating_dialogue: We have been looking at the numbers, and cesarean sections in the hospital have risen much faster than projected. We can't explain it.

director_regional_health_services.dialogue: For some reason people have been taking advantage of this service more than other services. It would be good to investigate this further, perhaps providers are pushing the services too strongly.

coach.dialogue: We can reduce the fee for this, but we need to think carefully about what other effects that will have on the program.

feedback.decrease_incentives: I'll research the best way to do this without having any undesired effects.

third_party_verifier.dialogue: They all seem to be legitimate, so I don't suspect fraud. Would you like me to go over the paperwork again?

community_verifier.dialogue: We have heard rumors of people going to the hospital and being offered services they don't want.

clinic_manager.dialogue: What's wrong with people getting outpatient services? It's better than the alternative.

feedback.maintain_current_rates: I'm glad to refer complicated cases to the hospital.

hospital_administrator.dialogue: Really? We haven't yet achieved the WHO standard of less than 10 to 15 percent of cesarean sections, so I don't think you should be worried. I am keeping a close eye on this. I am glad to see more cesarean sections because I have been referring a lot of complicated deliveries.

feedback.warn_providers_to_follow_protocols: I'll have my staff re-assess these practices.

twists.name: Money Troubles
twists.initiating_dialogue: Hello! Wonderful to talk to you today. I have a problem, however. Some of the traditional healers I work with are telling me they do not wish to refer to your facilities. They say they could make more money by selling the traditional remedies that you are replacing.

dep_minister_of_health.dialogue: This sounds like extortion to me. If they aren't willing to fulfill the contract, I say let them go.

director_regional_health_services.dialogue: This is just one of their negotiation tactics. Don't indulge them, and they will fall into place again.

coach.dialogue: Can we afford to pay them more? If so, that may just solve it.

third_party_verifier.dialogue: Sorry, I'm kind of up to my elbows in work here, I don't know if I have much advice to contribute to this situation.

community_verifier.dialogue: Wow, uh, I'm not really sure what I would do in your shoes. That might be in somebody else's job description, though.

hospital_administrator.dialogue: I would hate to lose their referrals. This program has been fairly successful.

feedback.increase_referral_incentives_1: Excellent! Everything will continue to run smoothly.
feedback.continue_with_plan_1: I warned you! Do not say I didn't warn you.
feedback.terminate_contract_at_end_of_year_5: What? This is very foolish. I hope you reconsider.

twists.name: Mismanagement
twists.initiating_dialogue: I was visiting the hospital for my coaching meeting, and they are still not following the clear fund management guidelines. I think they're pretty clear, why aren't they sticking to them?
